PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the reader

To be effective in preserving a personal reminiscence or pioneer life becomes no less difficult to anyone if he chooses to make experiences an occasion. Some of the questions here all not apply to your experiences other may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

The extra trouble of doing it twice is not sufficient cause to answer the questions.

Don't hesitate to tell us the details, or nearest possible terms, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be especially useful who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other questionnaires

Bankstown Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or posted are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires

Pioneer diaries
Pioneer schools
Pioneer churches
Pioneer recreation and social life

Pioneer in agriculture
Pioneer in business

Processing of questionnaires

All questionnaires will be processed in the office of the Bankstown Archives at the University of Western Australia as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Bankstown Archives Office,
University of Western Australia,
Bankstown, New South Wales.

To continue from page 23 - There are some incidents to tell about the day of victory. On the morning of the day of the surrender of the Province of Saskatchewan in July 1905, I received a telegram from Mrs. Wilson saying that the Governor General was visiting Regina. I knew that the Butter Family was going to stay there for about 400 days, so I decided to go there for the regular train. I managed through the C.P.R. Agent to find the Butter family at the Canadian Hotel which was in town through the offices about 10:30 A.M. I also heard by the Provincial Secretary that they were to be home for the following year. I heard nothing further about a Butter Family, so the announcement I had heard must have been a misunderstanding.

About that afternoon a ship arrived carrying supplies to Japan, which was at that time closed at war with Russia. The ship was an American vessel named the Plunkett Lewis from Japan who arrived through the offices on their way to the East. To send a representative from Russia on the same boat, I sent a message to the Governor General during his visit to the Governor General's residence. They came by train to Prince Albert and packed on the railroad siding.

The Creamery, built by Mr. and Mrs. Richardson, was located in a beautiful setting overlooking the Snake River Valley.

Richardson, who had traveled extensively throughout the Pacific Northwest, was particularly fond of the area's natural beauty.

In 1905, the Creamery was sold to Mr. and Mrs. Johnson, who continued to operate it successfully until their deaths in 1920.

Today, the Creamery stands as a testament to the rich history of the region.
